{{otheruses}}
 
{{otheruses}}
−
'''Ethics''' (from the [[Ancient Greek]] "''ethikos''", meaning "arising from habit") is a major branch of [[philosophy]]. It covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept]]s such as [[right]], [[wrong]], [[good]], [[evil]], and [[moral true or false), or are they expressions of emotion, "implicit" imperatives, or something else? If they are truth-apt, are they ever true? If they are ever true, what is the nature of the facts that they express? And are they ever true absolutely (see [[moral absolutism]]), or always only relative to some individual, society, or culture (see [[moral relativism]] and [[cultural relativism]])?
+
meaning "arising from habit") is a major branch of [[philosophy]]. It covers the [[Philosophical analysis|analysis]] and employment of [[concept]]s such as [[right]], [[wrong]], [[good]], [[evil]], and [[moral true or false), or are they expressions of emotion, "implicit" imperatives, or something else? If they are truth-apt, are they ever true? If they are ever true, what is the nature of the facts that they express? And are they ever true absolutely (see [[moral absolutism]]), or always only relative to some individual, society, or culture (see [[moral relativism]] and [[cultural relativism]])?
     
A claim of "meta-ethics" is that ethical positions cannot have absolutes unless there is a stated and agreed opinion about the goal of the ethical standards within the community that claims ethical absolutes.
 
A claim of "meta-ethics" is that ethical positions cannot have absolutes unless there is a stated and agreed opinion about the goal of the ethical standards within the community that claims ethical absolutes.
